If everyone just knew the law, these statutory code-racket pullovers and 
encounters would be history. You don't have to show a cop a damned thing 
when you are pulled over or confronted. THEY, however, have to prove to you 
that they are indeed a real public servant, with 3 forms of ID, or they are 
committing multiple felonies in the "color of law" under U.S.C. Title 18, 
ss. 241 and 242. They also have to have either a sworn affidavit from an 
injured party (Habeas Corpus, 6th Amendment), and/or produce a written 
order of the court (usually a "bonded warrant") to lawfully detain, search, 
interrogate or arrest you, etc. Just keep asking them for their badge #, 
photo ID and business card, and if they refuse, say "I wish to go on my way 
unmolested, as is my UNalienable right as a private man (or woman)" and 
they must let you go, or it's unlawful detainment for the purposes of 
extortion (arrest in lieu of bail = kidnapping for ransom), and you can 
serve THEM a private notice of trespass upon your person (misprision of 
felony) and a claim for punitive and monetary damages, which may likely 
result in the revoking of their surety bond (and career) as a public 
servant. Time to shut down the gestapo racket, people.﻿

Section 241 of Title 18 is the civil rights conspiracy statute. Section 241 
makes it unlawful for two or more persons to agree together to injure, 
threaten, or intimidate a person in any state, territory or district in the 
free exercise or enjoyment of any right or privilege secured to him/her by 
the Constitution or the laws of the Unites States, (or because of his/her 
having exercised the same). Unlike most conspiracy statutes, Section 241 
does not require that one of the conspirators commit an overt act prior to 
the conspiracy becoming a crime.﻿

Definitions of Terrorism in the U.S. Code
18 U.S.C. § 2331 defines "international terrorism" and "domestic terrorism" 
for purposes of Chapter 113B of the Code, entitled "Terrorism”:
"International terrorism" means activities with the following three 
characteristics:
▪ Involve violent acts or acts dangerous to human life that violate federal 
or state law;
▪ Appear to be intended (i) to intimidate or coerce a civilian population; 
(ii) to influence the policy of a government by intimidation or coercion; 
or (iii) to affect the conduct of a government by mass destruction, 
assassination, or kidnapping; and
▪ Occur primarily outside the territorial jurisdiction of the U.S., or 
transcend national boundaries in terms of the means by which they are 
accomplished, the persons they appear intended to intimidate or coerce, or 
the locale in which their perpetrators operate or seek asylum.*
"Domestic terrorism" means activities with the following three 
characteristics:
▪ Involve acts dangerous to human life that violate federal or state law;
▪ Appear intended (i) to intimidate or coerce a civilian population; (ii) 
to influence the policy of a government by intimidation or coercion; or 
(iii) to affect the conduct of a government by mass destruction, 
assassination. or kidnapping; and
▪ Occur primarily within the territorial jurisdiction of the U.S.
18 U.S.C. § 2332b defines the term "federal crime of terrorism" as an 
offense that:
▪ Is calculated to influence or affect the conduct of government by 
intimidation or coercion, or to retaliate against government conduct; and
▪ Is a violation of one of several listed statutes, including § 930(c) 
(relating to killing or attempted killing during an attack on a federal 
facility with a dangerous weapon); and § 1114 (relating to killing or 
attempted killing of officers and employees of the U.S.).
* FISA defines "international terrorism" in a nearly identical way, 
replacing "primarily" outside the U.S. with "totally" outside the U.S. 50 
U.S.C. § 1801(c).﻿

The problem with challenging DUI check points is the people who challenge 
don't understand the law.  Lower courts and the Supreme Court have already 
held that DUI checkpoints are not a violation of the Constitution. 
 Therefore they are legal.  If a person is driving a motor vehicle on a 
public highway the police have the right to ask the driver to produce a 
driver license or identification.  Passengers are not required to produce 
identification unless they are being detained for an alleged crime.  A 
recent court ruling stated that a police dog is an agent of the police and 
therefore the laws that pertain to the police pertain to the dog.  E.g. if 
the officer can't smell narcotics, then the dog's keener nose requires a 
search warrant.  If the officer observes narcotics in plain sight, then a 
warrant is not required.  So if some marijuana is in a plastic zip lock 
baggie inside of a paper bad, the police cannot look in the paper bag 
without a warrant.  On the other hand if the baggie is clearly visible then 
the officer need not obtain a search warrant. Appellate court and Supreme 
Court case law can be found on-line.  Everyone should research what the 
police can and cannot do.  You can download and print a copy of the case 
wherein the Supreme Court ruled a police dog is an agent of the police. 
 Keep a copy of that decision in your glove box and show it to the police. 
 Then, if they use a dog to do a sniff test it cannot be considered a 
harmless mistake.  When that happens you will have standing to sue for 
violation of your civil rights.﻿

If people have nothing to hide--simply complying usually ends after a 
couple questions and then you're relinquished to proceed on with your life. 
DUI check points are designed to keep drunk drivers off the streets. Most 
people who know somebody victimized by retards under the influence, behind 
the wheel, can appreciate the gesture and as citizens in what America likes 
to pretend is a civilized society--I don't get why there's so much static 
and pushback when cops try to do their job. I mean profiling is one thing 
and yeah, that's a dick move...but a DUI checkpoint isn't targeting anybody 
but everybody.

Resisting arouses suspicion--this kinda behavior brings about undesired 
experiences and you have nobody but yourself to blame. Educated idiots are 
the worst kind of people...they know enough to be dangerous.

Being educated is completely worthless when you don't exercise your 
freedoms and knowledge in a judicious manner. Knowing state constitutions, 
statutes, and bylaws better than agents of the law proves what?! That you 
know how to turn a routine inquiry into a 20 minute ad hoc search of your 
vehicle?

I might apologize for insensitivity but America keeps glorifying dumb sh*t 
like this and then wonders why cops are so antagonized and responding with 
increasing measures of police brutality. The media has criminalized the 
notion of civic police officers. You poke the effing bear--it's gonna snap. 
Whether you're wearin' blues or not...if you keep messin' with me but think 
there will be no retribution--you're a moron. Testing people's limits is 
foolish, whether they wear a uniform or not, but especially more foolish 
when they wear a uniform and are in a position to bring unpleasant 
experiences to your life in a legal context. Go ahead, mess with your 
garbage man...see if they skip your curb and let it pile up on your 
premises, mess with your postman...bet your mail starts disappearing. You 
push people and wonder why the push back. That relates to Newton's Laws of 
Motion in terms of for every force of action there is an equal or greater 
reaction.

At least to this kid's credit--he was compliant AND respectful. Just being 
a douchebag passive-aggressively.

How anybody thinks a DUI checkpoint is an infringement on personal 
liberties is beyond me--it's brainless. Drunk drivers kill people all the 
time. It's a civil service.

point, but it's not yet.These cops (and this kid) are all idiots. Contrary 
to popular belief, your 'Right to Travel' does not apply here. The 
operation of a motor vehicle is a privilege that you applied for, took a 
test for, and entered into a contract to operate a motor vehicle with your 
state when they granted you the license - notice that it says drivers 
license, not drivers right. These privileges are now subject and governed 
by the laws of your state and county. That includes check points. If you 
want to exercise your right to travel unabated, walk.Further, the fact that 
you setup the camera ahead of time and then stopped means you are complying 
with the check point and looking to make an ass of yourself and this 
officer - with the planned intent to do so. All you essentially were 
successful with was holding your own when he asked you to roll down the 
window. On every other instruction, you caved. If you're going to really 
try this 'right to travel' bullshit - then don't stop next time and let's 
see how far you get.﻿

If you are stopped while operating a motor vehicle you DO have to show a 
license to operate it and you MUST show proof of registration and Insurance.
Other than that you have no obligation to do anything else.

The other thing you have the right to do is REMAIN SILENT.
When you are stopped, for ANYTHING, open your window, show your license, 
registration and proof of insurance and then SHUT UP.

DUI checkpoints ARE Constitutional, it's been through the courts many times.
The Cops DO have the right and authority to stop you, based on their very 
clear mandate to preserve Public Safety.

We still have an operating Legal System in this country, if you feel that 
you were wronged take it before a Judge.

I've been stopped once at a checkpoint- it sucked because what usually 
takes 25 minutes took me almost 4 hours. By the time I got to the 
checkpoint, if I had been drunk I'd have already sobered up (but I don't 
drink). I just rolled my window down and answered the questions. Then I was 
on my way. While I absolutely agree with standing up for one's rights, I 
also understand DUI checkpoints. I've been hit by a drunk driver, and I 
used to be a paramedic who saw countless innocent people die because of 
drunk drivers (usually the drunk wasn't injured or had minor injuries). I 
don't blame the cops for doing DUI checkpoints whatsoever (on a personal 
level), but I think these jurisdictions need to invest in some serious 
training for these officers. Most of these cops truly do believe they're 
saving the world, but I don't think they realize that sacrificing rights 
for security erodes rights AND security. Most police deal with bad people 
so often, they become conditioned to think everybody is bad. Classic 
Pavlovian conditioning. Instead of trying to get certain cops fired, I wish 
more people (like the OP) would point out systematic flaws. Good job Bobby 
Hill on not making it personal, but making it about the flaws in the 
system. It's because of people like you that police departments are 
beginning to provide much-needed training on Constitutional liberties & 
rights, and police officers are beginning to truly understand their jobs. 
They aren't there yet, but I think it won't be too much longer before some 
serious citizen-inspired Constitutional training will revolutionize the law 
enforcement community. Because honestly, I think very few people actually 
think anarchy (no police ever) is a viable civilized option.﻿
